1587258725_15rKpUB9rz2YzS5vFmuNprwbQbRFg.body:
If you mean on general Internet, you can set up your DNS server to resolve the "special domain" you like if no other public DNS servers accept such domain. However the most issue is how you gonna persuade other people to use your DNS server rather than default ones distributed by DHCP or other public DNS such as 8.8.8.8 .
An alternative way is to add a line in hosts file in the OS to statically resolve the domain, if your website also got a static IP address. But still the same issue, how you gonna persuade others to add a line in their hosts file for your website.

1592403341_12MBVCw8iNrKvgTrV5NMPtPf6Z5V2.body:
> Maybe you will have latency issues with "always Tor" peers, but this is normal even on normal internet.
I guess you may have some very terrible latency issues, which could up to seconds or even minutes (in very terrible conditions) since you cannot control the access routine. Assuming A is in China while B is in USA and they are trying to have a 2P game. A may have no direct connection to nodes in USA so it may first connect to another node in China and then that node need to find another node until it find a way to USA, which literally equals gaming under multiple proxy servers compared to connecting to game server directly.

Also the uptime is not guaranteed. There are always times that only very few routes available to get A and B connected. It's just like sometimes cold Zerosites take very long time to load, since nodes with that website data cached are all offline. And when it comes to gaming, time critical data cannot even get cached.

1594835373_14g2gXnsZdEPShFJkGdh5W3eGXmKz.body: Actually you can do more than that. By running that caddy on a computer with public IP or a VPS, you can access to ZeroNet wherever you are, without using ZeroNet client and to wait for things to sync up. This is insecure though. Also, if you run a Internet website and it's CGI rendered, by fetching Zite first (HTML, JS, CSS, assets, ...) from the caddy then insert it into the website, you can even display ZeroNet contents inside your Internet website.

There are actually benefits (though niche and minor) in the network of China. e.g it's basically semi-legal to use pirated software, movies, musics etc. in China so some Chinese forums and network storage services are good places to hunt down resources.

> [hkpeace](#comment_14_1GVfTPghbWnBKbRWpYpkRCKgMi4wFecie2): Did the Zeronet founder nofish see the message? 
When you send something, other peers have to cache and resend that data so other peers could receive them. If huge amount of data is allowed to send on ZeroNet by default then it would cause very heavy burden on peers' storage space. You have to choose one to scarify, storage space or file size and ZeroNet chose the latter since it's meant to be a website service rather than a file storage service e.g. IPFS.
You can still bypass the space limitation by joining hubs that allow huge files.
